description: Kate Seabury It's another exciting day for us at Audible. Our product "Channels" comes out of beta today and includes first listens to the amazing original content our outstanding team had been working so hard on. To say I am lucky to be a part of this is an understatement. Working for Amazon and still being able to take risks and break down notions of how business models for spoken audio are "supposed to work" is beyond exciting. I hope you give it a listen and let me know what you think. Always happy for feedback. Cheers to our amazing Channels/Originals team!

Kate Seabury  shared  The New York Times 's  post . His photos transcended fashion and told us amazing stories about New York. What he gave us were really lessons in anthropology, I think. For me reading The New York Times will never feel the same again. I always hoped I'd see him on his bicycle when I finally moved to NYC. What a loss.   Thanks for alway bringing fun and lightheartedness to journalism, Mr. Cunningham. You'll be sorely missed.

description: Kate Seabury Yesterday was a fantastic day. Aside from spending it in D.C. with some of the most important people in my life in a place overflowing with hope and love, a project I have been working on for the last two months finally launched.   I started '100 Stories' the day after November 8. My intentions have been to share stories of amazing women whom you may not often hear about. These people are working very hard to make sure their communities and our country keep working toward goodness for all of us.   I am especially excited to share the first one, as this person is someone who has always inspired me. I hope you'll check out the project, and please let me know if there is someone you think I need to talk to. Onward and upward we go. Maria Kate Seabury

description: Kate Seabury Need a listen this morning on your commute? The first episode of 100:1 is out as a podcast today, wherever you listen. Episode one begins with the deaths of two young black men: Freddie Gray, in 2015, and Len Bias, in 1986. The ties between their deaths are unsettling, but, together, they illuminate how the anti-crack drug laws of the 1980s set policing on a new course of lethal aggression against black Americans. Listen, learn, love it, and leave a review.

description: Kate Seabury I figured I would write something insightful about turning 30 while I was on this big solo adventure. I'd let the winter air in the Andes sweep over my fingers and offer me its profundity. Surely, all these amazing thoughts have just been waiting to pour out of me!  That profundity I was waiting for never came (does it ever?!) What I did get was lots time to reflect on my MANY fortunes. That list is so deep, and I feel so underserving.   So with that, I say: thank you universe, thank you friends, and thank you family -- for teaching me SO many things. But, thank you more for still letting me realize I know nothing. Kate Seabury
